**The Vienna Assignment**
I was in Vienna to take photographs. This was usually why I traveled. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light fell on different surfaces and how a single photo could capture the spirit of a place, a city, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture, as long as I had film in my camera. My rule was simple: finish one roll, load another, and keep looking for new shots. 
I had a moment of success when a photo I took of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became popular worldwide. It was just luck, but they say you create your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer. I thought it was a smart choice, but life had other plans. The mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped, especially after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photos, and I was getting paid for it, which I thought was good.
The assignment came about by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*, which featured London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a nice payment for capturing the beauty of my city in different seasons. I knew that some of my best work would be ignored because it was just a picture book, not something meant to challenge people’s views.
After I submitted my winter photos of London, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for reasons I didn’t need to know. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the job. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, while other photographers were not. I was happy to go because things were not going well for me at home. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great.
They put me up at the Europa hotel in the old city. I had visited Vienna before with my wife, but it had been a busy and hot trip, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in the cold January weather would be different. As soon as I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs, I felt excited. I was ready to take great pictures.
On my first day, I didn’t take any photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to enjoy the atmosphere. The weather was cold and still, just like the grand buildings from the old empire that shaped the city. I didn’t want to see what Schussner had done in other seasons; I wanted to create my own version of Vienna.
A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. So, I took my time, observing everything until I was ready. The next morning, I woke up early. The snow from the night before made Stephansplatz look beautiful and almost empty. I struggled to find a way to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its tall spire reached into the grey sky, while at ground level, it was huge and heavy in the center of the city. I realized I might have to take a partial shot instead. In that weather and at that time, it could still be magical.
Photography has always had a sense of magic. Even the early photographers felt this before they fully understood the science behind it. You can watch a blank piece of paper turn into a photograph in a dark room. Even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Maybe that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in a strange way.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

**Art History**

This idea is similar to thinking that knowing how a dish is made takes away from its taste.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is difficult because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and those who faced wars and droughts are long gone. The reasons why they settled in certain places or formed families and communities are now forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot go back in time to see what happened. However, computer modelling allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and environments and fill them with virtual communities—digital people that have some needs and abilities like real humans. **Photography**
Over the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture many aspects of human life. In this short time, photography has improved its ability to record moments in time and space, allowing us to see both large and small things. It has given us images from faraway places, distant parts of space, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express what it means to be human.
However, the idea of recording events visually has a much longer history. The first known images date back to about 35,000 years ago during the Upper Paleolithic period. We are not sure why early humans created cave paintings. They might have recorded real hunting events, served as magic to help with hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply made daily life more colorful. These early images are deeply connected to human culture.
Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and what role they play in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has always given special importance to visual images. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a truthful visual record. The camera worked like the human eye, capturing images that looked very similar to what we see in real life. This ability to fix images chemically allowed photography to capture natural moments.
At the same time, photography was seen as a sophisticated art form, producing images that artists had worked hard to create. Ironically, because photography seemed so realistic, many believed that everyone could easily understand photographs. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander said that even the most isolated person could understand a photo of the sky, whether it showed the sun, moon, or stars.
However, as global communication grew in the late 20th century, we must consider how much photography can cross cultural differences. Is photography limited by cultural rules like any other form of communication, such as language? Has our familiarity with photographs made us overlook the complex ways they convey reality? Photography is often seen as a convincing form of evidence, making it easy to confuse our view of the world with its photographic representations. For instance, it is common for someone to show a photo and say, "This is my grandson."
Since its invention in 1839, photography and how people view it have changed a lot. This change may be partly because photography has moved into what we might call "mythic time." Its original role as a record-keeper has evolved, and photographs, once close to the photographer and subject, have become historical documents. These images often tell us more about the people and society that created them than about the subjects themselves.
I want to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not only reflect culture; it can also inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance in the 15th century without recognizing how the development of perspective changed visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a major role in creating the media culture of today, while also bringing the harsh realities of the world into our homes.

**How to Write Poetry**
Teaching people how to write poetry can be tricky. It is important to be creative, but one wrong move can lead to confusion. I believe that for beginners, the best way to learn is through reading a lot, writing often, and letting your imagination flow freely, as long as it doesn’t become chaotic. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others can express their feelings through writing during tough times. Some writers follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration to strike. All approaches are valid, as long as they are not just following strict rules. The key is to find your own voice and nurture it, allowing it to grow until it can stand on its own.
**The Short Story**
In a short story, it is important not to have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used when necessary to explain something important. A memory from the main character can help move the story forward, but it should not slow down the action. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different perspectives quickly, keeping the reader interested. Writing too much can ruin a short story, but being brief doesn’t mean you should just summarize the story. The conflict and action in a short story should be as strong as in a novel, but every word must be meaningful in a shorter format.
**Screenplays**
Writing a screenplay for a film is similar to playing chess. Most players make mistakes along the way. We may not know everything, but we understand enough to play. We can sometimes see a few moves ahead, and that feels good. As we learn more about chess, we realize that it is more about long-term strategy than just short-term moves. We start to see the game as a whole, not just individual moves. In both chess and screenplay writing, the more you practice, the more you understand the complexities involved.
**Looking at Writing**
Humans naturally want to communicate, as seen in how children talk. However, no child is born knowing how to write. Charles Darwin pointed out that while speaking is instinctive, writing is not. Language exists in all cultures, past and present. Although languages change, they do not necessarily become better. Children learn to speak without formal lessons, and when they are together without a common language, they create their own. In contrast, writing systems have been developed only a few times in history and started as simple codes that improved over time. Until recently, many children did not learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle with it. A group of children is unlikely to create an alphabet on their own. Children are naturally good at listening and speaking, but learning to read and write takes time and effort. We need to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it effectively.

I have never started a novel with so much doubt. If I call it a novel, it is only because I don’t know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader uncertain. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I do not know much about what happened to him in between our meetings. I could invent details to make the story more complete, but I do not want to do that. I just want to write down what I know.
To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story names I made up, and I have taken care to ensure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous, and he may never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more trace of his existence than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. However, it is possible that the way he lives and the unique qualities of his character may influence others, so that long after he is gone, people may realize that a remarkable person lived in this time. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know a bit about his early life may find something useful in this book.
I believe my book, despite its limits, will be a helpful source of information for my friend’s biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes of what was said, but I remember well what matters to me. Although I have put these conversations in my own words, I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the same liberty that historians do by putting words into the mouths of my characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and believable, as they would not be as effective if told in a simple way. I want my book to be enjoyable to read, and I think I am justified in doing what I can to make it so. A smart reader will easily see where I have used this technique and can choose to ignore it.
Another reason I feel nervous about this work is that the people I write about come from a different culture. It is hard to truly know people, and I believe you can only really know those from your own country. People are shaped by many things: the place they were born, the home they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they liked, and the poets they read. All these experiences make them who they are, and you cannot understand them just by hearing about them; you must live through those experiences yourself. Because you can only know people from a different country through observation, it is hard to make them believable in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because you can describe characters more briefly there. You give the reader general ideas and let them fill in the details. In this book, I do not claim that my characters see themselves as they truly are; they are seen through my own perspective, just like my main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**
At any time in history, the world of literature can seem confusing to those living in it. However, later generations can see clear patterns and important writers. Right now, there is a complex mix of different styles of poetry, groups of poets, and ways to present, criticize, and teach poetry. There are also different opinions about what a poet's role in society should be.
In general, the current discussion in poetry is about the distrust between serious 'literary' poets, who write poems meant to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their work in front of an audience. This division is not strict. Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common in many forms. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in village halls or members' homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to read and talk to students, and arts festivals often include poetry readings by well-known poets.
These events have many effects, and it is unclear how they benefit poets. For 'pop' poets, who write their work to be performed live, public readings are very helpful. Their poems are usually simple and can be understood easily in one hearing. However, when these poems are read on the page, their weaknesses in thought and technique become clear.
On the other hand, poets who are serious about their craft aim to create deep and meaningful work. They try to express strong emotions and ideas in a small space and use varied rhythms. Unfortunately, these poets may not be appreciated by audiences who are hearing their work for the first time. The risk is that they might only read their simplest poems to connect quickly with the audience, which may not represent their best work.
Attending poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry from a book, but it can be enjoyable and helpful. Hearing good poets read their work, even if they are not great speakers, can show the audience how to understand the poems better. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems beforehand.
The main reason for popular poetry readings, which sometimes include music, is to help audiences enjoy poetry and see it as an art form for everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**  
Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this approach has its challenges. It is unrealistic to think that a person's story is a perfect reflection of their past. In an interview, both the interviewer and the interviewee influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and talks about their past. The final result is shaped by the historian's social position and their understanding of history, which may affect how the informant shares their memories. Historians must recognize their role in creating new evidence. The challenges continue even after the historian leaves. The informant's memories may be influenced by other sources, like the media, or by feelings of nostalgia or resentment about their past. These emotions can make the testimony seem more convincing, but they may not accurately represent the time being discussed.
**Animal Science**  
There are two main ways to study animal science: the physiological approach and the whole animal approach. Physiologists focus on how the body works, including how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create complex behaviors. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of animals in their natural state and the factors that influence that behavior. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists usually work in labs studying a few species, like rats and pigeons, while ethologists study animals in the wild and their natural behaviors. Although these two areas are different, they are starting to work together more. Physiologists often claim that their methods are more fundamental, but understanding behavior also requires studying it at a behavioral level. Behavior has its own structure that we need to understand. For example, trying to explain how a bird builds a nest by only looking at nerve cells would be like trying to read a book with a microscope.
**The Social Sciences**  
Students studying social sciences for the first time face a challenge: they must learn both the content of their new subject and the methods used to study it. This means they need to understand not only the knowledge found in textbooks but also how that knowledge is gathered and organized. These two aspects are closely connected. While we all have experience with social life, social sciences go beyond common sense. Each discipline focuses on different parts of social life, uses specific methods, and has its own concepts. These basic ideas form the foundation of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.
**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. The Roman architect Vitruvius defined architecture as involving order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He also provided Greek terms for some of these concepts, likely based on earlier Greek writings that we no longer have. While utility and function are not part of his definition, Vitruvius does discuss the best designs for different types of buildings later in his work. Initially, he emphasizes the artistic side of architecture. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple structures in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Although these early buildings were not artistic, they contributed important elements that influenced later architectural ideas. Despite how elaborate classical temples may seem, they essentially started as simple, single-room huts.

As Chen looked at the sea, he felt a mix of sadness and happiness while thinking about Man Kee's future. He saw smoke on the horizon and then a ship shining in the sunlight. Chen put a coin in a telescope and tried to find the ship. At first, he couldn’t see it, but then he finally spotted it. It was a small, old tramp steamer. Chen lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It’s a special ship for people like us. It may look small and old, but we know it will take us back home when we are done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. 
Lily and Mui joined them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn’t want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was just a blurry white light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, and Lily could only see seagulls flying around.

**THE WELL**
I once read that if you dig a deep enough hole, you can see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my idea. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle, trying to help as I pushed the bucket away from the wall. As soon as it was free, I fell into the well. I hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved part of my plan. I saw strange lights, like the stars I usually saw in cartoons when a character got hurt. At first, I felt dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say.
You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You disappeared, calling for help. I waited a moment, then quickly climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard alarmed voices coming from the castle’s main door. I ran the other way, down to the passage leading to the moat bridge, and hid in the shadows. My mother and father appeared with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming, and my father was shouting for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows, feeling a mix of excitement and fear.
Then I noticed the drops of dirty well water I had left behind, forming a small pool at my feet. I looked back into the courtyard, where my father was shining a flashlight down into the well. I couldn’t believe no one had seen the drops. My mother was now screaming in a way I had never heard before, and it shook me. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but now things were more serious than I expected. What started as a fun prank was turning into something that could lead to serious trouble for me. I regretted not thinking this through. 
Suddenly, I had an idea. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit further and then fell dramatically on the stones. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I took a deep breath and said I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat. I claimed I crawled and swam through it until I got out and climbed up the bridge. I thought I was almost getting away with it until my father appeared in front of me. He asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed, and I realized I was only making things worse. I said the secret passage had collapsed after me and that the well was dangerous. I looked into my father’s eyes and felt like I was looking into a dark tunnel with no way out. 
He said, “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” with more disappointment than I had ever felt. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, looking troubled. He didn’t feel sorry for me because I had a scary adventure, but because he could see through my lie. He worried about what kind of person I would become if I kept lying. His pity hurt me more than my father’s words. It made me realize that both my actions and my father’s reaction were serious, and I couldn’t ignore them.

**REMOVAL DAY**
Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The moving van had the words 'Removers of Distinction' on it, and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, with his big fingers, carefully packed all the fragile items, while his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that looked over a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there felt present in the air, like dust.
When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be, especially now that he was an adult helping with the move. He was making sure Susan didn’t forget about the piano. Francesca, their daughter, was also there, being bossy and insisting that only she could take care of the valuable Steinway piano.
Fred noticed Susan was not crying and said, "That's something." Curious, Susan asked, "Do people cry?" Fred replied, "You'd be surprised. They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They are fine once they get to the new place; it’s just hard to see everything taken apart."
Susan could understand that feeling. If she had been alone, she would have warned the movers about the piano before they started. But Robert insisted it was the movers' job to notice any problems. The piano was now the last item to be moved, sitting proudly in the best room of the house.
Sitting on the bottom stair, since all the chairs were gone, Susan remembered the day they moved in. Today felt like that day played in reverse—the piano had been the first thing brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours to get it up. Little Robert watched in excitement while Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano! We can't!" They had to find a way to get it inside because Francesca was meant to be a concert pianist.
Eventually, Peter, her late husband, solved the problem. They left the piano in the garden while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder was hired to remove the first-floor window. Then, a crane was borrowed from a local farmer to lift the piano through the window. The children were overjoyed to see it come in, but it cost a lot of money, and they had to wait months to have it tuned.
"That's that," Peter had said. "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. The children became too busy to visit on weekends, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and how the banister rails were still not fixed perfectly. She should have warned the movers about the piano, but now it was too late. 
Suddenly, Fred asked, "Are you all right?" He reminded her that the piano was the last thing to move. Susan felt nervous as she moved away from the stairs. Robert and Francesca appeared to watch. Fred casually asked, "No tears then?" Susan was close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel so important. 
Just then, the piano appeared at the top of the stairs, with Fred guiding it down. "Easy does it!" he called out as they carefully brought it down and placed it behind the van. Robert was the first to laugh, and soon they were all laughing together, relieved that it was over. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone: Is DIY Literary Criticism Just Fun?**
From the beginning, one of the main ideas of the Internet was to allow open access. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early days, some technical skills were needed. Still, there was one area that became available to everyone: literary criticism. 
By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. Amazon allowed anyone to share their opinions and rate books with up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because each book had its own page, and new reviews appeared automatically. This helped Amazon fill its pages with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought, instead of just relying on publisher descriptions or professional critics.
Other online bookstores also offered similar features, but Amazon was the largest, controlling over 80% of the online market. This meant it had the most customers and received the most reviews, but it also faced some problems. Thousands of reviews were submitted every day, making it hard to check them all. A team of editors looked for reviews that followed Amazon's rules, such as no one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors. However, since reviewers could remain anonymous, it was easy for some to misbehave.
For example, authors could write positive reviews for their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the bad reviews of his first novel, so he wrote some positive ones anonymously to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed the fake reviews.
Authors could also comment on their own books by clicking a special link. Most authors used this to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for direct communication. However, Amazon did not always check if these comments were really from the authors, except for well-known writers. 
When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it received good reviews from the press. But many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and expressed their anger through negative reviews on Amazon. These reviews often disappeared after a few days. Despite this, Amazon saw the large number of reviews as good for business. 
Amazon monitored reviews closely, especially for bestsellers, to ensure they followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. For example, a classic children's book called *The Story about Ping* inspired humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in technology. One long review compared the book's story to Internet architecture, but such silliness was rare.
Most reviewers on Amazon took their writing seriously, and their reviews often provided a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books made it hard to have real feelings about them. This shows that making literary criticism available to everyone is a positive change.

**Art in Modern Times**
In recent years, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must go against the art of their time. Art is celebrated for being unique, revolutionary, and sometimes shocking. We enjoy admiring artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and say that some artists have gone too far, claiming that their work is no longer art. The media often expresses these opinions for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to always be new and different. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes and methods that are still present in today’s art.
We expect artists to be different from ordinary people, with special talents that make them stand out. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, and art was a part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work on their own and sometimes get frustrated if they try to connect with us.
**Picture This**
I want to describe a situation and ask an important question about it. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book that talks about the variety of pictures. The text asks, "What are they all about?" and then simply states, "There is no end to the different kinds of pictures." This may sound childish, but stay with me. 
After choosing the text, the artist asks someone to prepare a canvas for him and then to take it to a sign painter. He instructs the sign painter to write the text on the canvas in a simple way, without any fancy designs. The sign painter follows these instructions and writes the text in plain black letters on a white canvas. My important question is: is this finished piece a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is an unspoken rule for painters: once you find success in one style, you should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to keep producing similar work, and if they try something new, it can upset the audience. Gallery owners prefer to play it safe, and perhaps art buyers feel more comfortable with familiar styles. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have successfully broken this rule. 
Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying to change his style. He is moving away from the still lifes that made him famous to focus on the London Underground. Rimmington finds the railway fascinating. His earlier drawings of King's Cross Station led him to explore what happens underground. His new exhibition, "Underground Encounters," features 40 paintings and drawings that capture the unique charm of this hidden world designed for people on the move.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word "escape" because the villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to recover. So, I have come here to heal myself. Besides an old woman who comes from the village each day to clean, I am quite alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am like a feather floating in memories.
I mentioned the uselessness of art but did not speak about its comforts. The true comfort of my work as an artist lies in the fact that, in the quiet moments of painting or writing, I can rearrange reality and show its deeper meaning. Our everyday actions often hide the true beauty of life. For artists, creating art allows us to deal with the pain and challenges of daily life, not to escape from them, but to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why should we hurt one another?

**Family Business**
"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car on the way back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice with him, had just picked me and my trunk from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for the best end-of-school exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford." 
"So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Mightn't that be useful?" 
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious talk was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law. 
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!" 
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you are good at talking, and you enjoy performing." 
"I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see on TV." 
"Be that as it may," he said, gathering himself, "I feel like your heart is not in the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us." 
The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I could see many career options, and I wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I still found him intimidating. 
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly. 
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said, who often turned out to be right about these things. "It's a pity because you have the talent - the brains, the courage, the vision." 
"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice hated the business. 
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I had taken care of him since we were kids. It was not hard because I loved him. 
Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably - in a big house in London, attended nice schools, wore good clothes, and went to parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people - politicians, actors, and businessmen - and our home was always lively with good conversations. 
"I tell you what," my father said, continuing our talk. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me." 
"OK," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate choices and especially to avoid the sadness my father would feel if I disagreed with him. This was how he controlled us. 
So it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always with the easier tasks. I became one of the smarter students, with a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris that I planned to wear for my final exams. 
In my last term, my father came to see me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I focused and organized my thoughts, he might be right. I felt ready and confident. 
But then my father told me that in about a week, he needed me to do one last important task for him, the biggest project the family business had ever attempted, and he promised it would be worth my time. 
"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now." 
I could tell my father didn't understand the pressure I was under (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal. As he explained the task, I saw more clearly than ever how focused and determined he was, how he approached his work with energy and control. In his way, he was a kind of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important. 
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. Owning a house that requires strict budgeting is often not worth it. At first, it seemed like a good idea. Simon had been successful at work, and cases were coming in regularly. Lois returned to her job at the advertising agency two months after having twins and received a raise, bringing her salary to thirty-five thousand. She strongly wanted to move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed convincing at the time: their flat was not suitable for a family, they needed more space, a garden, and a separate room for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra space. Mornington Mansions was not a good address for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. Lois felt that even saying the name of their old flat lowered her status.
Lois decided that one of them should save money by using public transport. Since her office was on the other side of London, Simon had to be the one to travel by tube. The crowded journey made him feel resentful and unhappy. He often thought of his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had stayed as a boy. He remembered the smell of dinner and how his grandmother cared for his grandfather after a long day at work. She was a supportive lawyer's wife, always present at legal events and seemingly happy with her life. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and both of their jobs were essential for their lifestyle. Their home, the au pair, and everything depended on both of their incomes. Now, their hard work could be ruined by Venetia, who seemed to be in a bad mood.
Venetia must have come straight from court, and she was furious. Someone had pushed her to her limit. Simon blamed himself for not leaving his room earlier; if he had, the confrontation might not have happened. He remembered every word of her angry accusations. She said, "I defended Brian Cartwright today. He told me that when you were his lawyer four years ago, you knew he bribed three jurors. You did nothing. Is that true?" Simon replied, "He's lying. It isn't true." She continued, "He also said he gave shares in his company to your fiancée before the trial. Is that true?" Again, Simon insisted, "He's lying. None of it is true." His denial felt instinctive but unconvincing, and he felt guilty. The shock on his face turned to shame, reminding him of the fear he felt in his headmaster's office. He looked into Venetia's eyes and saw her disbelief.
If only he had been prepared. He now knew what he should have said: "Cartwright told me after the trial, but I didn't believe him then, and I don't believe him now. He will say anything to make himself look important." Instead, he had told a more dangerous lie, and she knew it was a lie. But why was she so angry? What did his past actions have to do with her? Who made Venetia the judge of their legal practice? Was her own behavior always perfect? Did she have the right to ruin his career? He was unsure of what she could do, but if this rumor spread, it could destroy him.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would be anonymous among people who didn’t care about the worn-out rented houses, messy gardens, or old furniture. However, I was wrong. People in the shops, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize you, even if you don’t know them. The beautiful roses from my neighbor’s garden remind me that gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about the summer outside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed some herbs to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. It is a small garden in London, where plants have to grow tall or spread out to survive.
“Been doing some clearing, I see,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leaning out of her window. She is a writer with several unpublished stories, and I sometimes help her with them as an English teacher. I have her latest manuscript with me now. “How’s the work going, Jaz?” I ask. “For goodness sake! In no other job do people ask you about your work so many times a day,” she replies, then continues, “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy and sad. She knocks on my door. “So, you’re on holiday now, lucky you.” She sits in the chair while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, acting young. “I should’ve gone into teaching. Writers don’t have holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither.
“So, what are your plans for the holidays?” she asks. I feel overwhelmed by the empty days ahead. Hot sidewalks covered in melting gum, walks to the shops, and sitting alone in the park. “Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” My heart races as I ask. “Of course I will,” Jaz says, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A nice bed and breakfast?” “No, I’ll be with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were eight.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction.
“Going back to your roots. What do you think of my work so far?” Jaz asks about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven’t read much. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and returning her manuscripts. I decide to be honest for once. “Let me give you a little tip,” I say. “What?” she asks, surprised. “Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good. A little less self-centeredness, a bit more fiction…” “Teachers!” Jaz replies, acting like a rebellious student. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,” I say. My advice sounds a bit old-fashioned. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but then I suddenly remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now. She used to wink at us and say, “I’ve had my moments.” We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, like knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, we also have a need to learn about our broader history to understand our future, both as individuals and as a nation. Heritage helps us feel a sense of continuity; knowing about the past can give us confidence about the future. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. There may be parts of our national heritage that we do not like, but it is still a part of who we are, and it can be comforting to feel connected to something larger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being. It influences our customs and material culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, in modern society, many of these oral traditions have been lost. Now, we often look to places and buildings to understand our past. It is very important to preserve these connections as a way to honor our ancestors' identities.
**The Fens**
Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England called the Fens became very important. After the book was published, people asked me why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about this area. The simple answer is that I found the Fens interesting because they seemed flat and empty, which provided a good setting for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are not really flat or empty. They are uniquely English but also strangely different. It is surprising that there is a place in the middle of England that many people find unfamiliar, especially since many other areas of Britain have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, seemingly simple yet deeply mysterious. While writing my novel, I did not explore the Fens extensively, as I prefer to create imagined worlds rather than seek strict facts. However, trying to imagine the Fens is important because, as shown in Edward Storey's book, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant just putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard to understand. Today, accessibility should mean more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and create emotional connections. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers, and they have started offering similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real objects, not replicas. They exist to provide a genuine experience with history. They show items that were used and had meaning at some point in time. This is their strength and what makes them different from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CDs. Museums that meet this challenge and create exciting displays and outreach programs will find that their competitors in "virtual history" can actually help them by increasing interest in real historical experiences.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly and on a large scale, affecting many people. This can make some people very focused on preservation and encourage others to think more about the nature of our towns today and their future. It can be argued that people who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more likely to value preservation than earlier generations because stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not a problem if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect social changes, such as population growth, welfare, and our needs.

**Einstein**
If you stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to sell products like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about what Einstein actually did, except that he created some complex theories called 'relativity', which are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to go against everyday experiences. 
Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thinking, a revolution that started modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to create a new, clearer description of the universe by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I did not trust any book that won awards because we thought they would be boring. Our mother often criticized us for this attitude, but our father would give us small coins as rewards for reading better books. He would also include some interesting books in our Christmas and birthday gifts, marked with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we thought most of his choices were 'boys' books', he did introduce us to some good short stories and, once, to a famous collection of poems.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851, 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous.' This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller suggested in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they sensed danger. This sound is sad. Early humans, who lived in dangerous places with wild animals, made desperate noises, and some of these sounds are still present in words today, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" and the Latin word 'mors' meaning "death". 
Many people avoided discussing the origin of language because they thought it was a topic for odd theories. However, recently, the study of how language began and evolved has become very important. Language likely started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and was a key tool in struggles for power. Sharing information was probably not the main purpose of early language, which goes against the ideas of philosopher John Locke, who described language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

**Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode looks at how to write reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. There are strict deadlines and limits on how long they can be. Once published, they are only read for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. Often, both the public and the writers believe that people only write reviews because they need money. Another reason might be that writers cannot spend all their time on a novel or serious book, so they do reviews instead.
However, writing reviews is a skilled job that requires different abilities. Writing a short review of six to eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from writing a longer review of six to eight thousand words for an international journal. A review in a weekly magazine, which is about fifteen hundred words, has challenges from both short and long formats. 
Reviewers must also think about their audience. Some readers may only skim the review, while others may be very interested and want a detailed analysis. Additionally, a reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This means that most reviewers also write other things besides reviews.
The American novelist John Updike, who does not think highly of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews when he is not working on his novels. He collects all his reviews, no matter how short, into books with modest titles. Some might think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last long, but it is understandable if they want their work to be remembered, especially if they believe some of their best writing is in those reviews.
I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been in academia, and most of my serious books are academic, which professors are expected to write. However, in the English-speaking world, there is no strict separation between reviewing and literary study. It is common for the same people to do both. The time has passed when other academics criticized professors for writing reviews, thinking it was a waste of time or not dignified. Complaints from non-professors about professors taking away their opportunities are also less common now, partly because there are many more reviews available, so almost anyone can write one.
I believe this situation is good for both readers and professors. Readers can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about, and professors benefit because writing reviews helps them stay connected to the public. It also reminds them that they need to communicate clearly with non-professors. While they may use complex language when talking to each other, they should make sure to be understandable when addressing a wider audience.
In conclusion, despite its importance, reviewing is usually a secondary job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will not turn out right. If you pull on a tangled fishing line in frustration, the knot will just get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some things can be done faster, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math in your head. But other things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they may fail, just like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.
Sometimes, saying "Think fast; we need results" can be unhelpful, just like trying to get a good night's sleep in a short time. We learn, think, and understand in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. There are sayings that reflect this: "He who hesitates is lost," and "Look before you leap." Both are true.
Generally, the mind has three different speeds of processing information. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to help me stay safe. It was only after that I realized what had happened. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer also does not have time to think about their next move. This quick reaction can be called our "wits."
The second speed is thought itself. This involves reasoning, weighing options, and solving problems. A mechanic figuring out why an engine won’t start, a scientist interpreting an experiment, or a student working on an assignment are all using this type of intelligence, which we often call "intellect." People who are good at solving these problems are seen as "bright" or "clever."
The third speed is slower and less direct. It is more relaxed and can be playful or dreamy. In this mode, we think things over or reflect. For example, sitting on a rock by the sea, listening to the waves, or being half-asleep puts us in a different mental state than when we are planning a meal or writing a letter. This slower way of thinking is just as important as the faster ones. Allowing our minds to wander is not a luxury; it is necessary, especially when life gets busy. We need both the quick mind and the slow mind.
Some everyday problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some complex issues can only be understood with a relaxed attitude. Recent studies show that slower, less deliberate thinking is good for understanding complicated situations. Deliberate thinking works well for clear problems. For example, deciding where to go on holiday is usually straightforward. But when we are unsure about what to consider or which questions to ask, we need to use our slow mind. 
If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work or whether to change careers, it may be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have long understood the limits of fast thinking and have tried to develop these slower ways of knowing. Recently, scientists have begun to study these slower, less direct ways of thinking. The field of cognitive science is showing that our unconscious mind can do many interesting and important tasks if given enough time. It can recognize patterns that our conscious mind might miss, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems more effectively than quick thinking.

**Maps**
The purpose of a map is to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, such as "a few hours' walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring was more about how easy it was to travel through the land than about the actual distance. 
Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Because of this, written directions were often just as important as maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not always show true directions. 
In the past, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs, which could be realistic or simple symbols, and their size showed how important they were. The way maps were made varied depending on their purpose and location, so it is important to understand the specific style used in early maps.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is mainly about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and the amount of information included on maps. To achieve this, cartographers have used knowledge from other sciences. For example, instead of finding direction by looking at shadows or stars, they began using the magnetic compass and developed tools to measure angles accurately.
As explorers learned more about the world, they tried to create maps of what they knew. Astronomers discovered that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to better mapping techniques. 
Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were no longer the only ones using maps. Soldiers, especially after the invention of artillery, needed accurate maps to understand the land for military purposes. This led to the creation of contour maps. Later, archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also had their own specific needs for maps.
Today, cartographers create maps that show various types of information, such as geological layers, climate zones, and land use. The growing recognition of the importance of maps in many scientific fields has led to a new era in cartography.
It is important to note that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid change, with old ideas sometimes existing alongside new ones. Cartographers have often had to wait for better tools before they could use their new ideas. Since it is easier to copy old maps, and because map publishers can be resistant to change, we should not blindly trust maps as the latest knowledge.
The many maps we have today are the result of significant human effort and thought. They provide a valuable record of human history, which makes studying historical cartography both interesting and educational.

I was taken into a young man's living room, which was a calm and cultured space surrounded by a messy collection of rooms where the less ambitious family members lived. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had encountered, and surprising evidence that a teenager had spent money on nice wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had received a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting school. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the famous composer Richard Rodgers. 
I also had big dreams; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. However, my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. If I had failed, it might have felt like a big deal, but I didn’t think it would be life or death. So, when Andrew suggested that I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was open to it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own tunes on the piano, and I could tell he was very talented. 
As he played songs from the many shows he had created at school, I remembered some of the best albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist, and I didn’t have much to show him except for my praise for his music and a seven-inch single of a song I had written with an unknown pop group. We agreed to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in musical theatre, but I thought I had met someone special who would succeed in musical theatre very soon. Even if we didn’t become top composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. 
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, the excitement I felt about a life in show business with Andrew had faded a bit. I would still look for ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs, but it was likely I would finish my exams and become a lawyer by twenty-five. My father believed I would grow out of pop music by twenty-one, which worried me because that meant I only had a few months left to enjoy it. But I thought it would be fun to see Andrew again, to go to a musical with him, and to write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about good food and Victorian architecture, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team. 
I wasn’t sure about the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but in 1965, I often doubted things. His talent was clear, and he claimed to have many important contacts. Soon, I was back in his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a nineteenth-century philanthropist who started orphanages. His story was important, but it didn’t excite me much. The hero seemed too perfect in Andrew's version, and the idea felt unoriginal, similar to Lionel Bart's famous show, Oliver. However, Andrew's strong belief in his music was contagious and somewhat justified. 
What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who would later be my agent for many years, often said, if there is a demand for one hamburger place, there is room for another. We could be the second hamburger place. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially for the funny songs. Andrew explained the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the titles, which were likely thought up by his school friend who had tried writing before. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first set of lyrics for the musical. I didn’t realize it at the time, but that day marked a change in my career.

**Language**  
You and I are part of a species that has a special ability: we can influence each other's thoughts with great accuracy. Language is so important in human life that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking to each other. When people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct.' This means that people know how to speak in a way similar to how spiders know how to spin webs. Web-spinning was not created by a genius spider and does not require special education or skills in building.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are mainly caused by the air around us, greatly affect the lives of animals and plants. Climate can strongly influence the appearance of landscapes. For example, warm and wet conditions all year allow tropical jungles to grow, which are full of different species. In contrast, cold and windy areas can only support a few types of living things. The daily weather patterns that create the climate are caused by large air masses rising and mixing, as the atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement happens because the air rests on a spinning Earth. Since air is light, it does not move at the same speed as the Earth and tends to lag behind. However, the sun is a more important cause of air movement.
**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, my job included serving drinks, but I was also responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I spent several days training to make coffee, learning a lot about how to clean and maintain the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key principles for making a perfect, rich cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was not as easy as it seemed, and I thought I might have to go back to simple tasks like cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn how to do it well."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often struggle with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are perfect subjects for the camera because it can show the entire artwork and then zoom in on the details. However, there are very few TV series that successfully show both the enjoyment and complexity of these arts. A good example of this problem is Robert Hughes's eight-part series on American art called *American Visions*. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he has almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to an art style that British galleries have ignored. I expected the series to focus on famous artworks, but instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in its art and architecture.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market is less regulated than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is a normal part of this industry. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of scarce metals high have found the opposite is true. More minerals are being extracted, and the cost of raw materials is going down. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To explore the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your accommodation, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available.
