**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the things that make us different from animals are very recent. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for warnings like 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings suggest that there are not many absolute differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a unique genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. We only have clear evidence of human art from around 35,000 years ago, with famous cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent burst of creativity makes us different, we need to consider how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for enjoyment, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas to others, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong serves clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by enjoyment. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, suggesting they do not sing just for pleasure. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris, but people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
Human art styles change quickly. For example, Roman authors wrote about geese honking 2,000 years ago, and they still do today. However, human art evolves so fast that even casual museum visitors can tell that a painting from the 20th century is newer than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work, but they might confuse two mid-20th century artists named Congo and Betsy. In reality, these artists were chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day, seemingly for his own enjoyment, and he got upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot claim.
These paintings by our closest relatives blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. You might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their art. However, this argument is not very strong, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. In the past, children's stories featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes squinting into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. Today, such characters are rare in stories and in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that incredible journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have cost everyone their lives and made the expedition very difficult.
This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn't come back since no one had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will be surprised by the word "kind." The team faced terrible challenges: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn't experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn't mean we didn't struggle the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. Climbing the high dunes was torture for us and the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time did not allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do this now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."
Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet, when I think of my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. By that measure, the desert does not compare."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to fit into the sameness of modern life."

Life Without Gadgets**
Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful devices that make life easier and save us time. However, this belief can be misleading. For example, using our fingers does not use up energy like our machines do, and doing things by hand does not harm the environment. 
After a frustrating experience with a broken word processor, which cost a lot to fix, Susan began to think that gadgets are often not worth the money or the hassle. She started to let her household gadgets break down naturally. This made her question what "time" technology really gives us. Does it just allow us to do more things that require even more gadgets? 
When her broken machine started making strange noises, she decided to leave it outside, where it now sits quietly. She enjoys not being tied to a noisy machine and can take her time with her sewing. Although she appreciates some gadgets, like her washing machine, she found joy in living without others. 
For example, they returned their rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped them spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. Susan has taken up sewing by hand since her old sewing machine is now just a table for plants. 
People often think they cannot live without their gadgets, but Susan believes that life can be better without them. She enjoys sewing while listening to the radio or talking with family. If the task is simple, she can even watch her favorite TV shows while sewing, which makes her feel less guilty about watching TV. 
Sewing by hand is not as hard as she once thought. It is relaxing and satisfying to see her work improve. She finds that things get done quickly, and she can enjoy a slower pace of life. She also enjoys washing dishes by hand, which allows her to daydream. 
Now, Susan looks around her home and wonders if they really need all their gadgets, like the freezer or microwave. She realizes they could save a lot of money by living without some of these electric devices.

The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst**
Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes a living by creating beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, which is located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is hard to tell if he is really in a hurry or just acting tough. Looking around the workshop, I see that he is indeed busy, with many pieces of furniture and wooden planks in different natural colors.
Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built a good reputation. His order book is always full for several months ahead, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right person to contact. 
Finding a furniture-maker is not difficult, as the craft is still alive in the countryside. However, it is harder to find a cabinet-maker who focuses on making well-crafted furniture with clean, simple designs. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people call themselves furniture-makers." He has high standards and is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He criticizes mass-produced items and craftsmen who make poor-quality pieces. This desire for perfection is a big part of Hurst's success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things."
Hurst learned his craft on his own. He explains, "I asked the right questions and picked it all up." Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return to him for more projects. He enjoys doing complete jobs for their homes, but he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want until it is too late. He prefers clients who are clear about their needs.
Although Hurst is proud of his work, he also recognizes the talent of others. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He is critical of craftsmen who take too long to make one piece and of students who focus on making fashion statements with their work. He believes that furniture should be practical and useful, not just a statement.
Hurst may be confident and direct, but he is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.
The third theory is about energy. It says that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted rules of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and strange habits. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the editor about various topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality. 
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism is the desire to be unique, while conformity is the desire to fit in. For many people, the need to be accepted and liked by others is stronger than the desire to stand out. 
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs, hold meetings, and organize events to share their interests or concerns. The key word here is 'common.' They seek others who understand what their friends and family might see as odd. Being part of a group can be comforting.
Most of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be different. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to show our individuality. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," or a new acquaintance might declare, "You must take me as I am." 
Anyone can choose to embrace their individuality at any time. Many successful people have done this. For instance, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it without giving up, you will surprise many people." However, this self-assertion is not the same as eccentricity, especially in the beginning. 
When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric. The key aspect of eccentricity is that it is natural. 
Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. A true eccentric does not care much about what others think. They act according to their true selves. This makes eccentrics different from enthusiasts, pranksters, clever criminals, show-offs, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often react to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. But eccentrics live their lives freely, without concern for what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet many important people in this field. One of the most significant is Barbara Ward, a small and delicate woman who has greatly influenced environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." However, I believe her most important book is "The Home of Man." Although its title sounds old-fashioned, it focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book beautifully explains the interesting world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see that their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's simple yet effective paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband but also to an exciting career in conservation. It defined my love for the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, reading this book made me feel hopeful again. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some people think humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living beings as a family, connected and inseparable. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered so much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five important British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study by the Book Marketing Council showed that many people say they buy a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually more relaxed about bad reviews. They believe that any mention in the press can help sales, as readers want to form their own opinions. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own feelings about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, there is still a problem with not enough attention given to paperbacks, which many people read. Weekly reviews often do not cover enough books, and even original paperbacks rarely get serious attention. Still, publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books. Most of our books are not by famous authors, so we rely on literary editors to give us space in their publications. Good reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. The impact of reviews on sales is complex. Good reviews can help launch a book and even a writer's career, but they need to work together with other factors like recommendations from readers and effective marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the United States, it is straightforward: a single review in the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of great reviews for people to notice a good writer. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books become bestsellers. The situation is unpredictable, but non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than on the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would pay attention. Today, it can also be the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that dates back to ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something special that reflects the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is very different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked the surprise gift he made for his wife and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he explains. 
Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change their roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available because they are still very popular. "People like handmade items," Graham says. "They want something a little different."
Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love unique items, and I feel satisfied when I see a simple shape turn into something almost lifelike," he explains. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds that more people are moving to the countryside and want to add special touches to their homes, which helps crafts like his.
Graham is now busier than ever, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world. He has noticed a lot of interest from buyers in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He felt disappointed and worried because he hadn’t earned any money in two years, and the film was his only hope to calm his angry bank manager. A sensible person in his situation would have found a job, maybe returning to television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel.
Although this decision seemed impulsive, the idea for the story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier on Dartmoor who told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The horse's owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans, who initially wanted to write a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after his disappointment with the film industry, he decided to write it as a book.
During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later reflected, "It was a strange time. I was observing people, but I felt very alone and like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and worried about how to support my children."
By the end of August, after returning home and writing the first half of the book, he felt the pressure from the bank manager. He needed to know if it was worth continuing. He bravely showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked about the potential advance, he suggested Evans might get $30,000. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel, along with the summary, to seven UK publishers just before they went to the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "You what?" The agent replied, "It's OK, I just feel something big is happening."
What happened next is now famous in publishing. Within a week of intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans said, "We couldn't believe it; we just sat there in shock. We had never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don’t know how it got there." They also didn’t send it to Hollywood, but soon major film studios were competing to buy the rights. Evans's UK agent wisely involved an American agent, who called to say, "I think we can get $3 million." They all laughed in disbelief.
As they agreed on this amount, the studios wanted to present their ideas to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called one after another, hoping to pay $3 million for an unfinished novel. Evans shared this story with me while we enjoyed coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It’s been like a fairy tale so far. I don’t want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people I like who have paid me so much money. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll bring in someone else.'"
He said he would stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to the world of chess. Chess has become more of a young person's game. After being away for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. He won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. Now, he is 49 years old, out of practice, and not in great shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new era of professionalism. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time, or they lose the game. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30.
The way chess is played has also changed. Much of it now happens off the board. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially because computers have changed the game. A small computer can store one million chess games and provide quick access to many games of an opponent. In recent matches, players have used large teams to find weaknesses in each other's strategies. The opening moves of a game are analyzed in great detail, and being well-prepared can be the key to winning.
Today, there are more top players than ever before, with many grandmasters competing for modest prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense situations, players must act quickly and decisively, similar to athletes.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready to compete again the next day. Most tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played every day, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in 1984 had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10 kg during that time.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game seem strange. However, it also made him a legend. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player in the world, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four academic writers discuss international volunteer work. 
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer work has a big impact on development. While volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a lot of money to participate in these projects. This money could be better used if donated directly to local communities, as it could pay for more labor than one volunteer can provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in improving their own careers. However, these projects can help develop people who may act ethically in their future careers.
B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and greater participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help create international social networks among ordinary people. In this way, the overall benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and local communities. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may only benefit them and not the communities that need help. Those who volunteer may continue to gain advantages while using local organizations and communities for their own growth.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that is more about helping wealthy Westerners than the communities they visit. It can also provide important technical assistance for development. When done well, international volunteering can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, allowing for the sharing of skills and experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness and commitment to fighting against poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the growing trend of wanting to help others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially in a time when people are skeptical of big governments and businesses. However, this focus on individual charity can ignore the need for democratic solutions and can reduce development to simple acts of kindness, which may not change the difficult situations faced by poor communities. While volunteering is a good act, when it is promoted as a solution for sustainable development, it can weaken the true understanding of development issues. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from the real problems of global inequality and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and we often need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group that included me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges tested five different models available now.
One model has a 'dual alarm function' that lets you set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. However, it does not let you snooze and then wake up later as I first thought. This model costs about the same as another one we tested, but it has a cassette player, which is a nice feature. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to a quiet morning. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size was a problem; it was as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that any clock radio he buys must leave enough space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it,' even though the clock he tested sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its stylish grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it while still half-asleep. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which caused some confusion when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out, which we all liked. But we found it difficult to set up, even though figuring it out made us feel cool and sophisticated.
Tom Granger thought another model, which has a built-in lamp, was 'unbelievably tacky.' He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was hard to position, and you couldn’t read by it since it only lit up the clock, which was already bright. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, which made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people, with its bright colors and fun design, which appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said, 'I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others.' 
The traditional controls made this model the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual says, 'the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time.' Paul Bridges laughed at this idea and said the model was 'terribly fiddly' and 'completely useless.'
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space,' and it had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, 'It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed all the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work.' He agreed that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All types of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, which makes their spines point outwards. This is a good way to protect themselves, but it depends on how many spines they have. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines. Because of this, they are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their rolling ability only as a last option.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs will stay awake all year.

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have approached him if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. Nervously, I introduced myself and asked for his signature, and to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of my sketchbook and then added some lively lines below. These lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a conversation, but since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. Still, I told Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend what I had. He noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and encouraged me to go back and talk to him again. 
So, with my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw his portrait, as I was afraid he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set up my pad, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled and made it hard for me to concentrate. He acted out funny faces and gestures, making it a challenge to draw him. Even though it was difficult, I felt he was testing my determination.
Eventually, Picasso relaxed and let me study him without distractions. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed to be in his own world, quietly focused on his thoughts.
When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with just one lively line. 
I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks. I thanked Picasso and asked if he could sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he was not going to give me another one! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? This article explains the tricks that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.
**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets know that customers like fresh food. They often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance to make the store feel fresh. Some stores even have bakeries that fill the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are also chosen to make customers think of fresh produce. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The way products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store customers visit the most. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are more likely to be bought, so manufacturers want their items placed there. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters. Stores also place related items together, like desserts near ice cream.
**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, customers pass by more expensive items on their way. Stores may also put popular products far from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting products along the way.
**D. Less Sells More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of selling many items cheaply. Instead, they create a boutique feel by showing fewer items, making them seem exclusive. Their success comes from good store design as well as stylish clothing.
**E. Tempting Totals**  
Food shoppers often pay more attention to the total cost of their shopping than to the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with more expensive items. They sometimes sell staples at a loss to attract customers, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They also get low prices by buying in large amounts or by promoting products prominently.
**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Customers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft by making staff ring up sales for small change.
**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores pay attention to lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.
**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different types of carpet to guide customers through the store. The main paths are often marked with one pattern, while sales areas have another. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use nicer carpets in sales areas to encourage customers to explore.
**I. In-Store Promotion**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see large pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales significantly.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, 58, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*, he called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing techniques, and Robin could show Chris how to sail. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to shore to practice climbing.
The climbing route was challenging, but Chris was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. When they reached a steep drop, Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. After Chris finished, Robin politely asked if he could climb down using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while Chris wanted him to use his legs. Chris was not very happy about it, but Robin managed to lower himself down safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin formed a strong friendship. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a big step from their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked for everyone's opinion first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making.
To be honest, Chris found sailing difficult and boring. He preferred the excitement of dealing with problems, but he struggled with spending many days at sea. He was not a natural sailor like Robin, who enjoyed fixing the engine and other tasks. Chris sometimes felt useless and found it hard to be so close to the other crew members on a small yacht designed for four people, but they had six on board.
When they reached Greenland and it was Chris's turn to lead the expedition, he felt nervous about being responsible for Robin's safety. There were times when Robin could have fallen and taken Chris with him, so Chris had to be very careful. He underestimated how hard it would be to climb the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain. Robin was not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin trusted Chris completely and just followed him. When it became too difficult, Chris knew they had to turn back, and Robin accepted this decision. 
Chris also knew that Robin was worried about their boat and whether it would be safe in the ice. Still, Robin wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a serious disagreement was on the yacht on the way home. They were taking turns to keep watch. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his shift, but Robin decided not to wake him, thinking he could handle it alone. Chris had almost fallen asleep the night before and felt that Robin did not trust him. He expressed his feelings, and Robin quickly reassured him that he had misunderstood the situation.
While they enjoyed their trip to Skye, they did not truly get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. Chris discovered that beneath Robin's tough exterior, he was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been part of human life for a very long time, with many different types in various colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this important part of our history.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for the winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we eat today.
**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in Britain. After the Norman Conquest, new apple types became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was a popular dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century. However, due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, apple production decreased, and more apples were imported. In the sixteenth century, King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many new apple types, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh from the Bounty brought apples to Australia, and Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa. The Pilgrim Fathers on the Mayflower also carried apples to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted apple nurseries across several states. He was seen as a kind man and became a part of many stories.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa found a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. When he showed it at a fruit event, a judge tasted it and called it 'Delicious'. In 1895, this apple was sold as 'Delicious' and became very popular worldwide.
**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts but chose to live a different life. As a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales, she took care of her family’s farm. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She moved it, and soon she was harvesting green apples that became famous worldwide. She said, "It’s just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her background.
**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, from India to Africa. However, most apples come from only a few varieties, chosen for their appearance or how well they travel, not for their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the different types of apples available. While some gardeners in the UK have kept old apple types alive, many varieties in the US have been lost. However, consumers are starting to want more variety. We cannot rely only on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity; we must work to protect and value the natural variety of apples and other foods for everyone’s benefit.
