Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing you to see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you can explore the wild on foot, track mountain gorillas, or go canoeing. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays.
**Ethnic Encounters**
A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara or the Maya of Mexico. Many of these cultures are at risk, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. Some involve village-to-village hiking, where you might stay in local homes or simple huts. Your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small daypack.
**Major Treks**
We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high altitudes. These trips may include staying with local people or camping in famous mountain ranges like the Himalayas or the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided.
**Wilderness Experience**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the beauty of places like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert, offering experiences few people ever have.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
These are relaxing holidays where we use local boats to explore. We sail through Upper Egypt, travel on wooden yachts in Turkey, and cruise the Galapagos Islands.
**Raft and River Journeys**
Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days, ranging from easy paddling to thrilling whitewater rafting. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. These journeys provide a unique view of the landscapes and wildlife along the rivers.

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner from Britain, visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is located ten miles south of the equator, on a beautiful mountain track that leads to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For the past three years, Nerurkar has trained in this area during the winter, but he had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his fourth trip, he decided to change that. He participated in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race.
Training at high altitude helps runners produce more red blood cells, which improves their ability to carry oxygen. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. Nerurkar's first race in Africa was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan, but he felt he had done well.
Nerurkar believes that Kenyan success is not only due to the high altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple and relaxed approach to running, and they genuinely enjoy competing. However, the most important question is how they train. During his time at the training camp, he learned about their training routine. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The living conditions are basic, with athletes sharing rooms in dormitories.
Each day, the athletes follow a strict training schedule that includes three workouts: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. Their day starts at six in the morning, and they cover about 40 kilometers daily, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. 
Life at the camp is simple. They prepare for breakfast with just a splash of water and a quick brush of their teeth. Breakfast includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After training, they often go to bathe in streams that flow from Mount Kenya's glaciers.
By the end of his stay, Nerurkar gained a deeper understanding of why Kenyan runners are so successful. Their achievements cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. He believes that the simplicity of their mountain lifestyle, their hard training, and their passion for running are key reasons for Kenya's success in distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem started in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The decline in advertising is happening all over the world. The main issue is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, target markets have become smaller and more specific. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not.
Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For big items like cars, you might only buy one every three years, and many people get their cars from their jobs. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even if you include all the other products and services you buy, it is likely that you do not purchase more than 400 different brands in a year.
Now, compare that to the 32,500 brands that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend very little on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are analyzed by Media Register. The average person buys only 400 of these brands, which is about 4 percent. This means that a large amount of advertising is wasted. When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about 6 percent of the ads are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent of the ads are likely wasted.
You might think you are different and that you do not respond to advertising, but most people feel the same way. The truth is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always some waste in advertising because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. Many ads have shown that they work. Advertisers need to reach a large number of people to find the few who will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested.
Even with careful targeting, advertisers cannot avoid all waste. For example, even the best direct mail campaigns do not get a 100 percent response rate. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every person they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all; they could contact those people directly.
Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is considered successful. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract 2 percent of the population is very successful, even though that is a small part of the total population. While mass media can be a cost-effective way to reach people, advertising needs to be more focused than ever to succeed again.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home**
Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral famous for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen. Second, it has the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is known as the greenest home in Britain.
The Vales have created a house that uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into compost for the garden, and heats the house using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located about 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's older buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists on this. The atmosphere is calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow, as the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to also avoid using mains water. They designed special toilets that compost waste, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.
Robert explains that they want to show people it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness. The only medieval feature of the house is its design, with a hall that includes the fireplace and staircase, reaching the full height of the building. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.
Soon, they will install solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden, which will help the house generate more electricity. While they will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances, they expect to produce extra electricity, enough to eventually charge an electric car. The only heating source is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they only use during the coldest winter days.
When Charles visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but Robert said it felt comfortable because there were no draughts and everything was at the same temperature. He noted that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures due to their clothing. He suggested that those living in older homes should consider going back to how people lived before 1900, although this idea may not be popular.
The secret to the house's success is its simple design, which means there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were sourced from local builders and installed by local craftsmen, making it affordable to build—costing the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not keen on this idea.

**The Camera Never Lies**
Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational and scientific man. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof of these tiny creatures. He published the photos with an article where he accepted fairies as magical beings. 
It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that a basic idea about photography is wrong: that the camera cannot lie. 
In fact, the camera can lie, and it always has. Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**
Throughout history, iron has captured the human imagination, and blacksmiths, the people who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were made by talented blacksmiths.
However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron features. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more creative approach to interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with manufacturers of gates and balconies often calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks with extra decorations.
Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and several events in the coming weeks aim to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are now more aware of the craft. 
Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson explains, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces are on display, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork.
Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He describes his style as letting steel bend and flow into shape when it’s hot, saying, "It's like drawing with metal in space." Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it’s very soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable."
Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by dark castles often seen in horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. She loves how steel feels cold and hard, and how it seems to last forever. No other metal can provide as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used for decorative purposes for many years to come, as long as we don’t have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**
I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying for me too. 
The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn’t plan to stop smoking, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, and I still do. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.
On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session in Birmingham called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; it wouldn’t be fair." I was there to write, not to quit, and I thought it was reasonable to expect that their method wouldn’t work on me. I really enjoyed smoking; it made me happy.
The counselor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. Could I also achieve other things?
In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it wasn’t a problem at all. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing things at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 
I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Dorothy Who?**
Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. Georgina Ferry has been testing her friends to see if they recognize Hodgkin. When she tells them she is writing a biography about her, she watches for their reactions. If they seem surprised and say things like, "Isn't there already a biography?" they pass the test.
Hodgkin deserves to be known because she achieved something very special. She won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964 for her work on important substances like penicillin and vitamin B12. She was a remarkable person, and her life shows the changes in the 20th century, such as the growth of women's education and the global nature of science.
When Georgina started her research, she wanted to read biographies of scientists. A friend suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of Hodgkin and also won Nobel Prizes. However, when she went to the bookstore, she found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. This surprised her, even though Pauling was a very important chemist.
Many people, including scientists, think that biographies of scientists are often boring. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, once said that the lives of scientists are usually dull. This belief makes it hard for publishers to sell books about scientists. Most biographies in bookstores are about famous artists, writers, or politicians, not scientists.
It is not true that scientists have less interesting lives than people in the arts. Some scientists are careful about how they present themselves in public. For example, a well-known geneticist said he would not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This attitude can make science seem less inviting to young people.
Fortunately, things are changing. More scientists are appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real individuals, not just researchers.
The world of publishing is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and often ignored the personal lives of scientists. However, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?" have shown that scientists can have interesting and funny stories. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are shown with their flaws, making them more relatable.
Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her work and also had a family. She had three children and a husband who was often away for work. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her scientific achievements, it shows how she balanced different parts of her life. 
Hodgkin's passion for science was a big part of who she was. Communicating this passion is a challenge for biographers because many readers may not understand complex scientific ideas. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.
It is unfortunate that many educated people do not recognize the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up often ask for her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she only needs her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is called dowsing. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. One of the most believable ideas is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.
Recently, during dry years, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with remote cottages or barns that are now holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She says, "You can't drill a well if there is a risk of waste getting into the water supply. The water we find is in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so we have to be careful about iron."
Electricity is also needed to run the pump, but it can be too costly to bring power across long fields. So, it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above an area with water.
Once she has identified possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick. The stick is forked and equal in length and width on both sides. She says, "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is very important to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."
Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, they agree on where to drill, but if they disagree, they will keep looking until they find a spot they both agree on.
Margaret is not alone in her abilities; many researchers and writers have been interested in this mysterious skill. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard for her family to continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? It might be fun to try something completely different! We arranged this for four people. Here’s how it went.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 and a mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant. 
Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. It was very different from her hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and told her it happens to everyone.
By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers outside, and Amanda felt even more nervous. She worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was done with a computer system. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to her, she had to say, "Pardon?" which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, and Amanda realized how tiring waitressing could be. She thought it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude. Amanda is quite shy, and she knew she couldn’t handle the busy Saturday nights. She was also disappointed with the tips she received. In the end, she was happy to return to her children, as being a mother felt much easier after her day as a waitress!
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy, who is 30, was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She had heard that Amanda's daughters could be cheeky, but she thought she could manage. 
When Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have three hours of peace. But she was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded her that she still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. 
At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. But when she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing. Cindy thought they would tire out soon, but she was mistaken. She tried to get them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun began! The girls kept asking for glasses of water, which was just a trick to get them downstairs to watch TV. Cindy realized how tiring it is to take care of two small children. There was no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Still, she enjoyed the day.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a primary school teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt great! She was unsure how to dress for school and hoped she wouldn’t stand out. At assembly, she faced about 400 students and hoped to blend in. 
In class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from Rosemary's school days. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There was a lot to do before classes started again. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which she enjoyed, and then a French lesson where the children practiced on her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, Rosemary was exhausted, while the children still had energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream to sell.
Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. It was hard not to taste everything! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not helped quickly, they can die, so they need daily checks. 
After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children because animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of farming is that there is no time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, making it hard to plan vacations. Rosemary only gets about three days off this year. Farming may seem romantic, but the reality is very different. The income can be unstable, and Hilary wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is surprising how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by forgotten composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces.
When you meet him, he looks younger than his age and has a bright and friendly personality, just like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a television program featured his work and development, filmed in both London and Sweden.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo, and his music career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to buy him a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played the trumpet all the time. His mother found the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra and convinced him to give her son lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, quickly recognized Hardenberger's natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher from the beginning, someone who loved the trumpet and sought out players worldwide.
Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and build a relationship with them. From the start, Hardenberger had a talent for finding the right balance and making that connection. He says that even as a child, his unique sound was already recognizable.
Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also avoided orchestras. Hardenberger collected all of Andre's records, and his parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player.
At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous. Instead, at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud agreed with Hardenberger's view that playing in an orchestra was not for him, comparing it to digging in the garden. Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience.
Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but made it to the second. Fortunately, he already knew most of the pieces for that round too. However, in the final, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even though he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.
Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication special, saying, "You risk destroying it by trying to explain. The power of music is that it can always move people."

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, and from this meeting, an unusual friendship develops. The author is skilled at showing how people react to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.
C. This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long and quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after the Second World War, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
D. After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle humor and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is approaching her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living is still a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her in her entertaining manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright spots of human experience.
E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences as they prepare to return home, their spirits lifted by life at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical day looks like for them.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and arrive at work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. There are times when I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed during surgery, but I sometimes worry about the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it is successful, it feels amazing, even if it doesn’t always work. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see outpatients and explain the surgeries. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to patients. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first few days, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with only a small part for design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they agree, we create budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to ensure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people, and good communication is very important. When their work arrives, I put everything together and send it to the printers. Managing several projects at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always close, and my day is never the same. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to the pub. If a client likes my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be later. I find it hard to relax, especially when I’m busy."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on some days, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I need to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude, but most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each place. Around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a local café for breakfast. In summer, I might work until 10 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I have an office at home, so when I return, I check messages and calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually set up a meeting in the evening. We focus on using old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes clients have strange ideas, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. It’s hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows me to be creative."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. I am the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site workers and solve problems. The contractors start at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we check the contractors' work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to discuss any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by going through the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these are very important to the artists, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, choosing songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also share my vision for the album with the marketing team. I manage budgets and spending. I usually leave work by 7:00 pm, and most evenings I go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to music to relax.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule to see if we have any clients visiting that day. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and helping them buy furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000, and we buy from auctions and private clients. Many items need restoration, so I work with restorers and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business. I also visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I usually go home at 5:30 pm, and it takes me about an hour to relax after work.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. I work for about an hour and a half at one station, then take a break and switch to another station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I often read about new air traffic rules between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job can be stressful, so I take sick days if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by getting the electronic sales system ready. I make sure someone is watching the cash register and coordinate lunch breaks for the staff. In the morning, I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to quickly gather many books for them. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new book titles with them. I need to decide how many copies of a new title we might sell. I ensure that new titles are delivered on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, and then I close the store and go home.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I assess financial risks for multinational companies, warning clients about potential problems in other countries. I provide three services: an online news preview, a security forecast for the next six months, and a travel security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will cover. My first news preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly. I write the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax in the evenings; I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps create change. Leadership is not about being tall or smart. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is very important. A good leader should be able to express their ideas clearly and confidently. Dixon says it’s about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."
**B. Discovering Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more potential for leadership than they think. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for good management.
**C. Comparing Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first boss led well, while the second just managed poorly.
**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules, while leaders create new opportunities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes that a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a struggling organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.
**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired, use that energy to take action.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different leadership styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead instead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to achieve them. Look at your job and identify areas where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career.
**F. Developing Leadership Skills**  
- Leadership does not just happen; it develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don’t assume everyone will immediately accept your leadership style. It might even push some people away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your leadership is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created a tense Cold War thriller called "Abyss." It tells the story of oil workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The characters, especially foreman Bud and his team, remind us of tough heroes from older films by Howard Hawks. The film has great production design and special effects, but the dialogue and character development are weak. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video version of James Jones's novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different take compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is poetic and mystical, Marton's film is more traditional but stays closer to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has some strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This film is loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel and is a fun swashbuckler that stands out among musketeer stories. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain, while Vincent Perez is an energetic hero, even if his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, who plays an acrobat-turned-swordsman, might be too serious for this light-hearted film, but he has his good moments. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama elements with so much humor and charm that it works well.
**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film tells a serious story. The detailed production and costumes make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on the historical details and not enough on the dark themes of the story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skills. The sound editing is excellent, making every sound clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement back. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act ruthlessly in the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic features "forty-eight international stars," according to its promotion. With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where battle-hardened soldiers wait for news about the invasion, are slow and drag on for both the audience and the characters. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it is best experienced on the big screen. Watching it on video does not do it justice.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is indeed very interesting. The story is about a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife when she is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the outcome is uncertain until the very end, with a surprising twist in the last pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a strong beginning and follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the rich during the Italian Renaissance. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church secrets, and serious crimes, but we always believe he will find out who is guilty. The story is complicated, and the book is a bit too long, but it is still very enjoyable.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective from first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who seems ready to investigate when a strange man suddenly dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, brave and adaptable Leah proves to be a strong character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator, who helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thoughtful discussion than usual. Parker always provides high-quality entertainment.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, as they investigate an attack and robbery at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and attention to unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book combines romance, money, and violence to create an exciting suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw shows actor Philip Fletcher in a new role as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels this is not how he wants his career to go. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time the shift from dark comedy to farce is not his best work.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are searching for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart, troubled robber make this book stand out from typical detective novels.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age have decided to take this big step. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. I have traveled before; after university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I came back, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Over time, I realized I was sacrificing my happiness for my job. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 
I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship and I don’t have strong career goals. I feel I should make the most of my freedom, if only for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and I’m already behind schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the start of the football season?” 
Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I’m putting it off because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that more people are realizing that adventure is possible: “People who always say ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are now understanding they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.”
For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career when I come back, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a sign of defiance!” 
For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling for a year was a time of change. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change my approach to live well as a civilian.” There are many reasons for people my age to travel, but some common factors exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today, we have a more flexible workforce. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Some companies even have career-break policies, knowing that if they invest in training someone, that person will return instead of going to a competitor.
Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, says more thirty-somethings are reevaluating their lives. “If you’re not happy with your job—and many people aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t forever. Travel allows you to step back and think about your life.” 
Is wanting to travel just another sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, believes he’s not running away. “I’m running towards something. I want to grab the things I want for myself.” But he also feels nervous. “I’ll miss my comfortable routine—going to the office every day, saying ‘hi’ to everyone, and having coffee.” 
I share Ben’s worries about leaving behind a stable life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be going on this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so difficult. Jennifer Cox points out that this is common. “There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to travel.” It may have taken a push to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll be proud to have taken this step. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt out of touch with new technology. In this passage, she shares how she changed her home into a productive workplace.
The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which I thought was lost due to technology. A quick look at my resume showed that I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. I felt that no one would trust me with a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads asked for experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought I had a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was known as the family technophobe; even calculators confused me, and I still didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.
I knew I had to act quickly to fill the gap in my career. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family and I won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with strangers from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.
The children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous, thinking I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I was not very skilled, I learned the basics. It was logical and easy to understand. With practice, I improved a little each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.
So, how has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk was always messy, and I often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track my income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. For a journalist, being online means I can research stories, ask for information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.
However, there are downsides to working from home. You can feel isolated without face-to-face contact. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Still, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment, but also for convenience, avoiding the daily commute to the city.
As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities are endless.

**The Tartan Museum**
The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum look very different from the historic city of Edinburgh where it is located. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.
You cannot miss the new Museum of Scotland. It stands out on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with its large yellow sandstone tower and unique buildings that look like cheese wedges, topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more cautious or even negative. Now, as the inside is almost ready for visitors, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.
The museum tells the story of Scotland through many interesting displays. It has a timeline to help visitors understand the history, but it does not force them to follow a strict order. The museum also showcases important national treasures, like the jewels of Mary Queen of Scots and silver from Holyrood chapel, without overwhelming visitors with national pride.
The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that visiting should be a fun and visual experience. The museum is designed for everyone, even those who know little about Scotland's history. However, Dr. Clarke is strict about what is displayed. He does not want to show imaginary scenes from the past, as he believes it is important to present the truth.
Visitors will see what experts know about the objects on display. The challenge is whether the stories of these objects can be told clearly using explanation panels, captions, and multimedia displays, with only about 30 computers available in the museum. With less than three days before the opening, it is hard to tell for sure.
Some things are clear, though. The views of Edinburgh Castle are breathtaking. Inside, the layout of the museum is striking. Galleries connect to each other in different sizes and shapes, with pale walls that look like large stone blocks and deep display cases. Natural light comes through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space where visitors can enjoy each item on display.
Thanks to a group of 12 young people from all over Scotland, the museum also has a Discovery Centre. They wanted to create a fun way to explore the displays. Although they did not get to ride through the exhibits, they succeeded in creating a hands-on center for children in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition area. The Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition. It will change every three years and features objects chosen by Scottish people that have had a big impact on life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is entertaining, it may not address more serious topics.
Overall, Dr. Clarke is right when he says that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it looks great from the inside and the top, but whether it fits well in its location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Newspapers**
The end of print newspapers may take a while. The word "transition" is nice and calming. Change can scare some people and challenge others. But transition means moving from the present to the future in a smooth way. However, the change for newspapers to go online is uncertain and uncomfortable. It might not even be a real process.
Many believe that this change will happen eventually. It is well-known that print newspaper sales are falling while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, the print sales of The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have dropped by 8% to 10% each year, but their websites are getting more visitors.
This might be true, but there are some things that don’t fit this picture. If print sales have not fallen much, maybe the crisis mainly affects newspapers. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries fell, Asia's sales increased significantly. News and current affairs magazines, which are expected to struggle in the digital age, also saw a 5.4% increase.
In short, while some magazine areas are declining, many are growing quickly. A similar trend is seen in books. Sales of e-readers like Kindle are rising sharply this year. However, when booksellers looked at the sales of physical books over the last six months, they found only a small decrease of 0.4%. This shows that people are buying both e-books and physical books.
The idea that young people are completely giving up reading newspapers is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read the main national newspapers. Different countries in Europe have different trends. In Britain, there has been a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.
These different trends suggest that the situation is more complicated than what many believe about the digital revolution. In the past, American media analysts thought that online advertising would help newspapers succeed online. However, digital advertising on newspaper websites is now decreasing, making those earlier beliefs seem outdated. 
Currently, 360 US newspapers, including many well-known ones, have started charging for online access. The best way to attract paying readers seems to be offering both print and digital access together. This means that print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. Print advertising also earns much more money than online ads.
However, maintaining both a website and a print edition is challenging and expensive for newspaper companies. Despite this, print newspapers still have a strong presence, while being noticed online is much harder.

**Photographing People**
People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with a person is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The camera can also change how people behave.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. If possible, have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of the camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. Avoid having the subject look away from the camera, as this can make the picture less interesting.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A picture is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don’t have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the photo. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the subject can focus on something else in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the viewer a sense of observing a moment. Candid shots can be very captivating, and the subject's expression is important.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they are a quick way to communicate feelings.
**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be powerful, the background can add more context. When including a background, avoid distracting details. Make sure the subject stands out against the background, which can be done by using a wide-angle lens.
**H. Interaction**  
Photos of people interacting, like talking or laughing together, often make great pictures. Couples, mothers with babies, and teams can create appealing shots. Look for moments of connection, like eye contact or a friendly gesture.
**I. People and Places**  
Many pictures of people are taken during trips. To improve these photos, use a wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position the people close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. A slightly higher camera angle can help achieve this balance.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met on holiday, a clear posed picture is good. However, family photos can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, creating better memories for the future.

**Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means she creates paintings that trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.
Not many artists choose not to sign their work unless someone asks them to, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She believes that the artwork is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes for an interesting magazine interview. She admits, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she even gets nervous when asked to be photographed.
After a little time, Sarah becomes more comfortable, and the interview turns into a fun and entertaining conversation. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she spent two years drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she was not satisfied with illustration and decided to work with a well-known decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and that sparked her interest. She left to start her own career, not knowing exactly where it would lead, but feeling hopeful.
Sarah's ability to observe details, which she developed through her illustration work, is very important for her art. She often gets asked where people can learn trompe-l'oeil, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she explains. She is always learning and believes that if you think you have mastered something, you should give up.
Sarah is honest about her weaknesses, saying, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also struggles with math, especially when she had to measure for a large project on a chapel ceiling. She thought to herself, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" This self-doubt makes her view her talent in a unique way. Sometimes she talks about her work in the third person, saying, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"
Her trompe-l'oeil art is exceptional and stands out from others who have tried to copy the style. She has completed many important projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes it look like you can enter two more rooms at the end of a hallway.
However, there is a challenge with trompe-l'oeil art: once people understand the trick, they might lose interest. Sarah knows this well. She says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination. That is the most important part."
Sarah believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal to the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients have clear ideas about what they want, while others do not. She emphasizes the importance of listening and understanding the client's vision. Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working on their projects. 
Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They seem happy with her work, which is why she is always busy, even though she tends to downplay her talent. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." 
While this may be true, you could never really get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be more widely recognized, and I am willing to take the risk of making her uncomfortable by praising her.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman looks at the important 'people skills' needed to succeed in your career.
A. The rules for work are changing. We are now judged by a new standard. It is not just about how smart we are or our training and skills, but also about how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new standard is increasingly used to decide who gets hired and who does not, and who gets promoted. It helps to identify who is likely to be a top performer and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future job opportunities. They focus on traits that are essential for success, which are different from what we learned in school. Doing well in exams is not as important anymore. The new standard assumes we all have enough intelligence and skills to do our jobs. Instead, it emphasizes social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are the 'people skills' that make up what we call emotional intelligence.
B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For many years, these qualities were called different names, such as 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills'. Now, we have a clearer understanding of these human abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence'. This is defined as the ability to understand and manage our own feelings and the feelings of others, and to use these feelings to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people think it just means 'being nice', but sometimes it requires being direct and honest, even if it is uncomfortable. Emotional intelligence does not mean expressing all feelings freely; it means managing feelings so they are shown in a suitable and effective way, helping people work together towards common goals.
C. More businesses are realizing that promoting emotional intelligence is an important part of management. The more complex a job is, the more emotional intelligence matters. A lack of these skills can limit a person's ability to use their technical knowledge. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that encourage collaboration have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and customer focus are important, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job around the world.
D. While a person's IQ does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we go through life and learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and improving their empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence and add these skills to our toolkit for success, especially now when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for struggling organizations, nor does it guarantee success. However, if we ignore the human aspect, nothing else will work as well as it could.
